member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Base64UrlEncoder
member.summary: Encodes and Decodes strings as Base64Url encoding.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Base64UrlEncoder.s_base64Table
member.summary: Encoding table

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Base64UrlEncoder.Encode(System.String)
member.summary: The following functions perform base64url encoding which differs from regular base64 encoding as follows * padding is skipped so the pad character '=' doesn't have to be percent encoded * the 62nd and 63rd regular base64 encoding characters ('+' and '/') are replace with ('-' and '_') The changes make the encoding alphabet file and URL safe.
member.param: string to encode.
member.returns: Base64Url encoding of the UTF8 bytes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Base64UrlEncoder.Encode(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts a subset of an array of 8-bit unsigned integers to its equivalent string representation which is encoded with base-64-url digits. Parameters specify the subset as an offset in the input array, and the number of elements in the array to convert.
member.param: An array of 8-bit unsigned integers.
An offset in inArray.
The number of elements of inArray to convert.
member.returns: The string representation in base 64 url encoding of length elements of inArray, starting at position offset.
member.exception: 'inArray' is null.
offset or length is negative OR offset plus length is greater than the length of inArray.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Base64UrlEncoder.Encode(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Converts a subset of an array of 8-bit unsigned integers to its equivalent string representation which is encoded with base-64-url digits.
member.param: An array of 8-bit unsigned integers.
member.returns: The string representation in base 64 url encoding of length elements of inArray, starting at position offset.
member.exception: 'inArray' is null.
offset or length is negative OR offset plus length is greater than the length of inArray.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Base64UrlEncoder.DecodeBytes(System.String)
member.summary: Converts the specified string, which encodes binary data as base-64-url digits, to an equivalent 8-bit unsigned integer array.
member.param: base64Url encoded string.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Base64UrlEncoder.Decode(System.String)
member.summary: Decodes the string from Base64UrlEncoded to UTF8.
member.param: string to decode.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.DefaultMessageRouter.GetEndpointsForConnection(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceEndpoint})
member.summary: Get all the online endpoints. When the endpoint is offline, there might be a need to notify user about it because there is potential message loss. Customer can choose to change the behavior by using a custom router. Note that this one is only called when the SDK is not able to identify where the connectionId is. When the outcoming connectionId happens to be also connected to this app server, SDK can directly send the messages back to that connectionId

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServerStickyMode
member.summary: Specifies the mode for server sticky, when client is always routed to the server which it first /negotiate with, we call it "server sticky mode".

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServerStickyMode.Disabled
member.summary: We the server sticky mode is disabled, it picks the server connection by some algorithm In general, local server connection first least client connections routed server connection first

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServerStickyMode.Required
member.summary: We will try to find the server it /negotiate with from both local and global route table, it the server is not connected, throw, If it is globally routed, this request will be always globally routed

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceEndpoint.ServerEndpoint
member.summary: Gets or initializes the custom endpoint for SignalR server to connect to SignalR service.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceEndpoint.ClientEndpoint
member.summary: Gets or initializes the custom endpoint for SignalR clients to connect to SignalR service.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceEndpoint.Online
member.summary: When current app server instance has server connections connected to the target endpoint for current hub, it can deliver messages to that endpoint. The endpoint is then considered as *Online*; otherwise, *Offline*. Messages are not able to be delivered to an *Offline* endpoint.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceEndpoint.IsActive
member.summary: When the target endpoint has hub clients connected, the endpoint is considered as an *Active* endpoint. When the target endpoint has no hub clients connected for 10 minutes, the endpoint is considered as an *Inactive* one. User can choose to not send messages to an *Inactive* endpoint to save network traffic. But please note that as the *Active* status is reported to the server from remote service, there can be some delay when status changes. Don't rely on this status if you don't expect any message lose once a client is connected.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Common.BackOffPolicy.CallProbeWithBackOffAsync(System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task{System.Boolean}},System.Func{System.Int32,System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Provides a synchronized mechanism of calling probing funcs by multiple concurrent callers. Each caller's probe func will be invoked exactly one time. The probe call may get delayed depending on the result of previous probe calls. The delay is controlled by getRetryDelay func and the number of consecutive failed probe calls.
member.param: this func returns a task with boolean result indicating if the probe was successful
this func returns a TimeSpan delay for a given iteration number
member.returns: A task with its final state and result matching the state and result of the task returned by the probe func. This task will completes after either of the following happens: - probe's task changes state to task.IsCompletedSuccessfully == true and task.Result == true - probe's task.Result == false / faulted / cancelled and the delay defined by getRetryDelay has passed

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ConnectionFactory.GracefulLoggerFactory.GracefulLogger.Log``1(Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.LogLevel,Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.EventId,``0,System.Exception,System.Func{``0,System.Exception,System.String})

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.GracefulShutdownMode
member.summary: This mode defines the server's behavior after receiving a `Ctrl+C` (SIGINT).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.GracefulShutdownMode.Off
member.summary: The server will stop immediately, all existing connections will be dropped immediately.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.GracefulShutdownMode.WaitForClientsClose
member.summary: We will immediately remove this server from Azure SignalR, which means no more new connections will be assigned to this server, the existing connections won't be influenced until a default timeout (30s). Once all connections on this server are closed properly, the server stops.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.GracefulShutdownMode.MigrateClients
member.summary:
Similar to `WaitForClientsClose`, the server will be removed from Azure SignalR. But instead of waiting existing connections to close, we will try to migrate client connections to another valid server, which may save most of your connections during this process.
It happens on the message boundaries, considering if each of your message consist of 3 packages. The migration will happen at here:
| P1 - P2 - P3 | [HERE] | P4 - P5 - P6 | | Message 1 | | Message 2 |
We do this by finding message boundaries on-fly, For JSON protocol, we simply find seperators (,) For MessagePack protocol, we preserve the length header and count body length to determine if the message was finished.
This mode always works well with context-free scenarios. Since the `connectionId` will not change before-and-after migration, you may also benifit from this feature by using a distributed storage even if your scenario is not context-free.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Connections.Client.Internal.WebSocketsTransport
member.summary: Copied from aspnetcore repo, TODO: refactor

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.MultiEndpointMessageWriter
member.summary: A service connection container which sends message to multiple service endpoints.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.MultiEndpointMessageWriter.WriteMultiResultAckableMessage(Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Protocol.ServiceMessage,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: For user or group related operations, different endpoints might return different results Strategy: Always wait until all endpoints return or throw * When any endpoint throws, throw * When all endpoints return false, return false * When any endpoint returns true, return true

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.MultiEndpointMessageWriter.WriteSingleResultAckableMessage(Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.Protocol.ServiceMessage,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: For connection related operations, since connectionId is globally unique, only one endpoint can have the connection Strategy: Don't need to wait until all endpoints return or throw * Whenever any endpoint returns true: return true * When any endpoint throws throw * When all endpoints return false, return false

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ClientConnectionScope
member.summary: Represents a disposable scope able to carry connection properties along with the execution context flow

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceConnectionType.Default
member.summary: 0, Default, it can carry clients, service runtime should always accept this kind of connection

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceConnectionType.OnDemand
member.summary: 1, OnDemand, creating when service requested more connections, it can carry clients, but it may be rejected by service runtime.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceConnectionType.Weak
member.summary: 2, Weak, it can not carry clients, but it can send message

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceConnectionBase.StartAsync(System.String)
member.summary: Start a service connection without the lifetime management. To get full lifetime management including dispose or restart, use
member.param: The target instance Id

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceConnectionContainerBase.StartCoreAsync(Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.IServiceConnection,System.String)
member.summary: Start and manage the whole connection lifetime

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceConnectionContainerBase.CreateServiceConnectionCore(Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ServiceConnectionType)
member.summary: Create a connection for a specific service connection type

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.SignalR.ReusableUtf8JsonWriter

member.name: M:System.Threading.Tasks.ForceAsyncTaskExtensions.ForceAsync(System.Threading.Tasks.Task)
member.summary: Returns an awaitable/awaiter that will ensure the continuation is executed asynchronously on the thread pool, even if the task is already completed by the time the await occurs. Effectively, it is equivalent to awaiting with ConfigureAwait(false) and then queuing the continuation with Task.Run, but it avoids the extra hop if the continuation already executed asynchronously.

member.name: T:System.Net.WebSockets.WebSocketExtensions
member.summary: Copied from aspnetcore

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsExternalInit
member.summary: Reserved to be used by the compiler for tracking metadata. This class should not be used by developers in source code.
member.remarks: A class originally defined in .NET 5. Copy here to use "init" accessor on target frameworks below .NET 5.
